newsitem.title: USA: US corporate bond issuance seen slow despite rally.
newsitem.headline: US corporate bond issuance seen slow despite rally.

text.p: U.S. corporate bond issuance is expected to remain relatively slow this week, despite a rally in the Treasury market triggered by a positive inflation report on Tuesday morning, syndicate officials said.
"There just aren't that many issuers waiting to tap the market this week," said one high-grade syndicate source.
A junk bond syndicate official said the Treasury rally could improve the pricing on the few high-yield deals that are in the pipeline currently.
He noted, "The real hope is that a firmer Treasury market could lead to a pickup in (mutual) fund flows."
In the high-yield market, Copamex Industrias SA de CV is expected to sell $200 million in seven-year senior subordinated notes in a 144 offering late on Tuesday.
Price talk on the notes, rated B1/BB, is 11 percent to 11.5 percent or 400 basis points to 450 basis points over the seven-year Treasury, market sources said.
Citicorp Securities Inc is the lead underwriter. Copamex is the leading integrated paper products producer in Mexico.
Also, Exide Holdings Europe SA is expected to price a rare mark-denominated junk-bond offering to European and American investors later this week.
Price talk on the 150 million mark offering of seven-year senior notes, rated B1/B, is 375 basis points to 400 basis points over the seven-year bund, market sources said.
Morgan Stanley & Co is the underwriter of the offering. Exide, the European unit of Exide Corp, is a manufacturer of industrial battery products.
In the high-grade market, a handful of new deals are expected for later this week:
-NatWest is expected to sell $500 million in perpetual bonds via JP Morgan Securities.
-Service Corp International, a Houston-based funeral home company, may sell $400 million in seven- and 12-year debt securities via JP Morgan.
-A&P is expected to issue $300 million in 10-year and 30-year bonds in a 144a private placement via Morgan Stanley later in the week.
-Food Lion Inc is seen offering $300 million in 10-year bonds via Salomon Brothers Inc and NationsBanc Capital Markets Inc later this week.
